Physicists Create Homemade Cosmic Dust, Which Could Help Them Figure Out How the Building Blocks of Life First Reached Earth
Cosmic dust normally comes from dying stars. The recipe for a lab-made version includes a few gases, vacuum tubes and electricity
Tiny specks of rock, ice, minerals or other chemical compounds float freely throughout the universe. This so-called cosmic dust contains ingredients crucial to the formation of stars, planets, comets and even people.
Now, using gases and electricity to mimic the harsh environment of space, physicists have concocted their own lab-made version of cosmic dust. The work, described in a study published January 30 in the Astrophysical Journal, could help researchers investigate how elements crucial for life reached Earth, and simulate how life might pop up elsewhere in the cosmos.
“It’s like we have recreated a little bit of the universe in a bottle in our lab,” says study co-author Linda Losurdo, a physicist at the University of Sydney in Australia, in a statement.
Researchers suspect that cosmic dust comes from dying stars. A giant one near the end of its life will grow very hot around its exterior, begin to break apart and “belch out … huge waves of carbon,” Losurdo tells the Guardian’s Donna Lu. It also expels hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and all the elements get bombarded by high-energy particles. This creates chemical reactions and results in what are called CHON molecules, which play key roles in the foundations of life.
Did you know? Stars create elements
These huge balls of gas are element factories. Massive stars convert lighter elements, such as helium and carbon, into heavier ones, like neon, magnesium and iron, via nuclear fusion. They release the elements when they explode in bright supernovas.
The stuff burped up by stars is “quite similar” to the materials found in meteorites, Losurdo tells the Guardian. Researchers often rely on these space rocks to study CHON molecules and answer questions such as how these molecules got to Earth. Some hypotheses include that they formed on the planet during its youth, were dropped off later by comets and meteorites, came during the solar system’s birth about 4.6 billion years ago or originated from some combination of the three.
But meteorites are rare commodities, as most that fall to Earth burn up in the planet’s atmosphere before reaching the surface.
So, Losurdo and David McKenzie, also a physicist at the University of Sydney, added nitrogen, carbon dioxide and acetylene, a gas with carbon and hydrogen, to tubes with air vacuumed out, mimicking outer space. Then, they blasted the gases with 10,000 volts of electrical potential for roughly an hour, creating plasma.
“You’re completing a circuit across the gas itself, so the gas is getting excited, electrons are flying off, creating an environment in which things want to bind and coalesce and aggregate,” Losurdo tells CNN’s Jacopo Prisco. “And that’s a very natural process. It’s something that we know for certain happens around stars.”
The energy sparked chemical reactions that created new compounds, including cosmic dust, which fell onto silicon wafers inside the tubes. Further analysis revealed that the lab-made dust emitted infrared light signatures similar to space-made dust, as previously detected by telescopes.
The new research is “a really beautiful method” that creates a substance similar to “what we think interstellar dust is like,” Sara Webb, an astrophysicist at Swinburne University in Australia who was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian.
“One very exciting possibility, which is probably further down the track, is … to use this kind of simulated cosmic dust in other organic chemistry experiments, to simulate early life formation on different types of planets,” she adds.
Damanveer Grewal, a cosmochemist at Yale University who was not involved in the study, tells CNN in an email that the new work bridges an important gap between telescopic observations and laboratory analysis.
It can also be used as a jumping-off point to test ideas about the origins of organics in space, he notes. “The findings suggest that complex organic matter forms readily in stellar environments and is not unique to our solar system,” Grewal says. “If these materials are widespread, it implies that the essential chemical building blocks for life are likely available to planetary systems throughout the galaxy.”

Money canât buy happinessâbut it might just buy love, or at least a little romance. Americans are expected to spend a record $29.1â¯billion on Valentineâs Day in 2026, with the average shopper set to shell out nearly $200 to delight their special someone.
Some are sticking with the classicsâbouquets, bonbons, and bearsâwhile others are leaning into their love lives once the lights go out with intimate essentials. And thanks to delivery services like DoorDash, all of these gestures can reach loved ones without anyone having to leave the couch. So, which states are leading with love? DoorDash looked at orders placed on the most romantic day of the year to find out.
The Most Romantic States, Mapped
DoorDash data shows that love is in the air across the U.S.âand thanks to the online delivery service, people donât have to brave the cold to send sweet gifts to their significant others. To figure out the countryâs most romantic states, DoorDash analyzed per-capita orders during Valentineâs week 2025, tracking traditional gifts like flowers, chocolates, balloons, and teddy bears.
The results? Most of the top 10 are clustered along the East Coast and Midwest, with Delaware taking the crown as the No. 1 most romantic state, followed by Maryland, Rhode Island, Ohio, and Michigan. And apparently, procrastination is part of the charm: more than 80% of flower orders were placed on Valentineâs Day itself, with deliveries peaking between 9 and 10 a.m., proving that love waits for no oneâ¦except maybe until the last minute.
The Most Intimate States, Mapped
Valentineâs Day orders arenât just sweetâtheyâre a little spicy, too. While Delaware claimed the top spot for romantic gifts, Nevada ranked first as the most intimate state in the U.S. Interestingly, Maryland, Rhode Island, and Ohio appear on both the romantic and intimate lists, playing up traditional romance with a little extra passion. With Utah in the top five and Arizona close behind at No. 7, the desert isnât the only thing heating up in the American Southwest.
To see just how Americans were celebrating intimacy, DoorDash analyzed per-capita orders of condoms, lubricants, and adult toys during Valentineâs week 2025. Protection was a top priority, with condom orders surging more than 100% above a typical day. Other sexual wellness products also spiked: lubricant orders jumped 95%, and vibrator orders rose 60% compared with the first-quarter average. Americans clearly have no trouble keeping things hot and hassle-free on Valentineâs Day.

articles.title: Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
articles.author: Redação
articles.excerpt:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait...
articles.content:
Rumors Suggested That Anne Boleyn Was a Witch With Six Fingers. Did This Elizabethan Artist Rework a Portrait of the Tudor Queen to Debunk the Gossip?
A new analysis of the Hever Rose portrait suggests that the painter deliberately modified an existing template to showcase Anne’s hands—with no extra digits—holding a delicate rose
In 1585, a Catholic priest living in exile published an unflattering description of Anne Boleyn, the mother of England’s reigning Protestant queen, Elizabeth I.
Anne, who’d been executed on charges of treason in 1536, had “an oval face of a sallowish complexion, as if troubled with jaundice,” the priest wrote. “She had a projecting tooth under the upper lip, and on her right hand six fingers.”
This purported extra finger—a characteristic sometimes associated with witchcraft during the early modern era—provided fuel for Elizabeth’s critics, who viewed her claim to the English throne as tenuous. (She’d been declared a bastard following her mother’s execution.)
Drawing on now-debunked accounts of Anne’s physical appearance, Catholics accused her of witchcraft, heresy and scandalous conduct, engaging in a “widespread and vicious” assassination of her character, writes historian Tracy Borman in Anne Boleyn and Elizabeth I: The Mother and Daughter Who Forever Changed British History. That negative reputation persisted for centuries.
Now, new research conducted for an exhibition at Anne’s childhood home, Hever Castle in Kent, England, reveals an early effort to rehabilitate the Tudor queen’s image. As Dalya Alberge reports for the Guardian, infrared analysis of the late 16th-century Hever Rose portrait of Anne shows that its creator deliberately reworked an existing template to show both of her hands.
“By clearly displaying five digits on each hand, the portrait acts as a visual rebuttal to hostile rumors and as a defense of Anne Boleyn—and, by extension, of her daughter Elizabeth’s legitimacy,” says Owen Emmerson, an assistant curator at Hever Castle, in a statement.
Did you know? Anne Boleyn and witchcraft
- Contrary to popular belief, witchcraft wasn’t one of the charges leveled against Anne during her trial. Instead, the second wife of Henry VIII faced contrived accusations of adultery, incest and conspiring to kill the king.
- In a 2023 journal article, historian Sylvia Barbara Soberton addressed many of the misconceptions surrounding the Tudor queen and witchcraft. She argued that Nicholas Sander, the Catholic priest who wrote the disparaging description of Anne, never actually described her as a witch, instead criticizing her for the crime of heresy. His words were later misconstrued due to an inaccurate translation.
- At the same time, Soberton pointed out that rumors of Anne practicing witchcraft circulated both during her lifetime and in the decades following her execution.
During the Tudor era, which lasted from 1485 to 1603, artists often based their likenesses of royals on preapproved templates or “face patterns” instead of painting from life. This practice—which proved particularly popular during Elizabeth’s nearly 45-year reign—helped monarchs assert control over their public personas and avoid the time-consuming process of sitting for portraits in person.
The Hever Rose portrait is based on a template known as the “B” pattern, which is perhaps best exemplified by an iconic image of Anne housed at the National Portrait Gallery in London. In this pattern, Anne is typically portrayed from the bust up, with a pearl “B” necklace around her neck and her hands out of view. Infrared reflectography scans taken at the Hamilton Kerr Institute at the University of Cambridge capture the moment when the Hever Rose artist decided to deviate from this established template by featuring Anne’s hands, which are shown clasping a rose.
“This preliminary design was laid down with confident, continuous lines, indicating that it was transferred from a pre-existing pattern rather than drawn freehand,” Emmerson tells the Daily Mail’s Wiliam Hunter. “At a later stage, however, the artist altered this plan. Anne’s hands were added in, cutting across the earlier design.”
In addition to analyzing the infrared scans, the Hever team performed a dendrochronology assessment of the portrait, dating the oak panel on which it was painted to around 1583. At the time, Elizabeth’s “legitimacy, succession and ancestry were under renewed pressure,” Emmerson told Smithsonian magazine earlier this year, and rumors about her mother’s supposed misdeeds ran rampant.
The pope had excommunicated Elizabeth in 1570, giving her Catholic subjects and fellow monarchs license to overthrow her. This situation was “compounded by the fact that she’s no longer of child-bearing age, she’s unmarried … so she cannot look to the future to promote her legitimacy,” Emmerson told the Independent’s Harry Cockburn last month. Critics of the Protestant queen looked to her Catholic cousin Mary, Queen of Scots, as a viable claimant to the English throne.
Given the timeframe of the Hever Rose portrait’s creation, Emmerson and exhibition co-curator Kate McCaffrey argue that “the artist was directed to alter the established pattern specifically to show Anne’s hands, carefully and unmistakably,” per the statement. Although McCaffrey tells the Guardian that “it’s impossible to say” whether Elizabeth herself commissioned this portrait, she believes that it’s “too much of a coincidence for it not to be in response to rumors.”
McCaffrey adds, “It’s Elizabeth’s way of not only reclaiming her own legitimacy and lineage but also restoring the legitimacy of her mother.”
Historian Helene Harrison first observed the potential connection between the Hever Rose portrait and the Catholic priest’s claims in her 2025 book, The Many Faces of Anne Boleyn: Interpreting Image and Perception. As Harrison writes in a blog post, “Anne’s [hands] seem deliberately splayed, almost as a message.”
The Hever Rose news isn’t the only explosive revelation shared in recent weeks by the castle’s curators. In January, Emmerson announced the results of a technical analysis performed by Lawrence Hendra, an art historian at Philip Mould & Company, who identified four paintings—portraits of Anne and Elizabeth, as well as Elizabeth’s half-sister, Mary I, and her paternal great-grandfather, Edward IV—as the work of the same artist. The four sitters share “the same underlying facial geometry,” despite the fact that they weren’t all genetically related, Emmerson told Smithsonian. (Anne was linked to Mary and Edward through her marriage to Elizabeth’s father, Henry VIII.)
As Emmerson explained to the London Times’ Richard Brooks last month, the artist may have used the same facial template for each of the four portraits, cutting and pasting Elizabeth’s face onto those of her predecessors “to show a legitimate and God-ordained line of succession.”
Viewed together, the new analyses testify to a time of crisis during Elizabeth’s reign. Besieged by threats to her throne—including multiple plots to replace her with Mary, Queen of Scots—Elizabeth looked to portraiture as a powerful propaganda tool to spread messages emphasizing her resemblance to past monarchs and subtly disavowing falsehoods about her mother.
Overall, the Hever Castle exhibition seeks to move past the many myths surrounding Anne by bringing together more than 30 likenesses of her.
“Very few portraits of Anne Boleyn have undergone this level of scientific study,” says Emmerson in the statement. “By combining technical analysis with historical context, this exhibition brings us closer to seeing Anne as her contemporaries might have done—not as a myth, but as a real woman.”
“Capturing a Queen: The Image of Anne Boleyn” will be on view at Hever Castle & Gardens in Hever, England, from February 11, 2026, to January 2, 2027.

articles.content:
This Carved, Painted Zapotec Tomb Is Mexico’s Most Important Archaeological Discovery in a Decade
The tomb features the carvings of a huge owl head and at least three probable ancestors
Archaeologists in Mexico have uncovered an incredibly well-preserved Zapotec tomb dating back to the early seventh century. The tomb boasts intricately carved walls, murals and sculptures—including a massive owl, a Zapotec symbol of night and death.
It’s the “most significant archaeological discovery in a decade in Mexico,” said Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo, at a January press conference, per Live Science’s Kristina Killgrove.
Researchers unearthed the tomb in the valleys of central Oaxaca, a state in southern Mexico, according to a translated statement from Mexico’s National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH). Officials were clued into the tomb’s location by an anonymous report of looting at the site, per Live Science. Oaxaca is the native land of the Zapotecs—also called the “Cloud People”—a pre-Hispanic population who have lived among its highlands and valleys since the sixth century B.C.E.
The entrance of the stone tomb’s antechamber, its small front room, is decorated with a complex sculpted portrait. A large owl head protrudes from the overdoor, its curved beak open, and inside its mouth is the sculpted, painted face of a man wearing wide hoop earrings. Per the statement, the man was likely a Zapotec lord—perhaps the ancestor to whom the tomb was dedicated.
The entrance is flanked by intricately carved, painted door jambs, one depicting a woman and the other a man. Each figure holds artifacts and wears a cloak, skirt and large headdress. According to a video from INAH, these full-length portraits may depict other ancestors buried in the tomb. But they could also represent the tomb’s guardians, per the statement.
Inside the antechamber is another doorway, leading into the burial chamber. Above this doorway is a frieze of engraved tombstones carved with “calendrical names,” per the statement. The ancient Zapotec calendar, composed of 260 days divided into 20 months, represented days through animals and other natural images. The people used the calendar to name gods and important people: Each was identified by a specific symbol associated with their birth date, reports Live Science.
The walls of the burial chamber are covered in murals. Painted in ochre, white, red, green and blue, the murals depict a parade of people walking toward the entrance of the tomb. The people carry bags of copal, resin from tropical trees that Mesoamericans—including Zapotecs, Maya and Aztecs—commonly burned during ceremonies.
Ancient Zapotec tombs are reputed for their intricate construction and decoration. In 2023, five 2,000-year-old Zapotec tombs were unearthed in Oaxaca. One of them was composed of multiple chambers arranged in a cross-shape, and it was decorated with red and yellow murals depicting warfare.
Quick facts: The tombs at Monte Albán
- Also in Oaxaca is Monte Albán, which was the capital of Zapotec society between about 500 B.C.E. and 850 C.E.
- Monte Albán’s sprawling ruins include plazas, pyramids, a ball court, tunnels and likely hundreds of tombs. These elaborate ancient funerary chambers are spacious, vibrantly painted and filled with riches.
Researchers are conserving, studying and protecting the recently discovered tomb, per the statement. This includes stabilizing the mural paints, which are vulnerable to degradation from roots, insects and environment changes. To learn more about the Zapotec rituals and funerary practices associated with the tomb, researchers are analyzing its inscriptions, ceramics and iconography.
Claudia Curiel de Icaza, Mexico’s secretary of culture, said at the press conference that the tomb is an “exceptional discovery” for what it says about Zapotec culture and “its social organization, funeral rituals and belief system, preserved by the architecture and the murals,” per CNN’s Jack Guy.
Curiel de Icaza recently visited the tomb, alongside local residents, INAH researchers and the governor of Oaxaca, report La Jornada’s Ana Mónica Rodríguez and Jorge A. Pérez. Before entering the chambers, Curiel de Icaza blessed its entrance by pouring a shot of mezcal on the floor.
One INAH researcher paused at the entrance, realizing they would be entering a tomb that doesn’t belong to them, La Jornada reports. The researcher raised their hands and asked permission of the wind, earth and Zapotecs to enter.

articles.content:
A Smithsonian magazine special report
The National Gallery of Art Acquires 17th-Century Masterpiece by Baroque Painter Artemisia Gentileschi
“Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy” is the gallery’s first work by the Italian artist, who was one of the most influential female painters of her time
The National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. has announced the acquisition of a rare painting by the Baroque artist Artemisia Gentileschi, the 17th century’s most influential female painter.
Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy, painted circa 1625, will be on view beginning later this month. It’s the gallery’s first painting by the Italian artist, and art historians consider it to be one of her finest works.
“It is a momentous occasion to bring Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy into the National Gallery’s collection as our first notable example of Artemisia Gentileschi’s remarkable work,” Kaywin Feldman, the gallery’s director, says in a statement. “This acquisition marks a major addition to our historical holdings, reflecting our continued commitment to deepening our collection, and in turn, expanding public access to great works of art.”
Quick fact: Artemisia Gentileschi’s trailblazing career
In 1616, when the artist was in her 20s, she became the first woman to be admitted to Florence’s Academy of the Arts of Drawing.
Throughout history, other paintings of Mary Magdalene were “largely portrayals of death and penitence,” often placing her “alone in a setting which is unplaceable, nondescript,” wrote the Cleveland Review of Books’ Kameryn Alexa Carter in 2023. In Gentileschi’s interpretation, the illuminated saint bares more skin than usual and appears in a moment of passion. However, in the 17th century, these states weren’t seen as mutually exclusive.
“That binary that we now use between the spiritual and the erotic was actually then closer, and entwined in a way that is very hard for us to understand,” Eve Straussman-Pflanzer, the museum’s curator and head of Italian and Spanish paintings, tells the Art Newspaper’s J.S. Marcus.
A skull, cross and ointment jar—items that she’s usually associated with—are notably absent. Instead, the viewer is drawn to focus solely on Magdalene’s expressions.
The painting has striking similarities to a work by the same name painted by Caravaggio in 1606. Caravaggio had worked closely with Gentileschi’s father, and his style profoundly influenced her work.
Completed just two decades apart from each other, Gentileschi and Caravaggio’s Magdalene paintings have followed a strikingly similar path over the past 400 years. Both vanished from the public record and were assumed to be lost to history before they were ultimately rediscovered.
Caravaggio’s piece emerged in 2014, while Gentileschi’s was discovered in the south of France in 2011. The latter was subsequently sold for $1.1 million in a 2014 auction—several times the estimated price.
Widespread recognition of Gentileschi’s talent and influence on Baroque art is a relatively recent development.
“Female painters were always there but slipped from history along the way, mostly in the 19th century,” Andrea Rygg Karberg, director of the Nivaagaard Collection in Denmark, told the Sunday Times’ Julia Buckley in September 2025. “We lost half of history. Sofonisba [Anguissola] and Artemisia were really famous in their own time, but they were only rediscovered in the 1970s.”
The Nivaagaard, a small gallery on Denmark’s eastern coast, made history last fall by becoming a world leader in Renaissance and Baroque-era paintings by female artists after outbidding a group of international museums to acquire Susanna and the Elders, another painting by Gentileschi, for an undisclosed sum.
Earlier this week, one of five known self-portraits by Gentileschi—and likely the earliest, painted when the artist was nearly 20—sold at a Christie’s auction for a record $5.69 million, per Artnet’s Eileen Kinsella. The portrait depicts the painter dressed as St. Catherine of Alexandria, and it has been requested for an exhibition at the Nivaagaard beginning in 2028.
After experts conduct a technical analysis of its pigments, Mary Magdalene in Ecstasy will be placed within a 17th-century frame and exhibited on the main floor of the gallery’s West Building.
